name: Kirk's Dik-dik
description: Dik-diks are small, slender antelopes with short brownish fur. They have an elongated, mobile snout, large eyes, and a crest on their head that they raise when excited. Males, smaller than females, have short, pointed horns.
spread_note: Two separate populations in eastern and southwestern Africa
food_note: Shoots, young leaves, buds, tubers, fruits
image_alt: Kirk's Dik-dik, photo: Petr Hamerník, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 55–72 cm, tail rudimentary, shoulder height 35–45 cm, weight 3.8–7.2 kg
reproduction: The female is pregnant for 180 days and gives birth to one fawn.
attractions: Dik-diks are among the smallest antelopes in the world. They live in pairs on small territories of 0.05–0.3 km², usually for life.
